river/lake flooding.direction_statement: Climate change will cause changes to river and lake flooding severity and frequency that will depend on the location, season, and local watershed factors.
river/lake flooding.direction_confidence: It is difficult to make confident statements regarding the direction of climate-driven changes to river and lake flooding severity, without added local information about flood mechanisms and local watershed conditions.
river/lake flooding.magnitude_confidence: Estimating the magnitude of changes to river and lake flooding due to climate change is difficult without undertaking detailed local assessments.
river/lake flooding.impact_statement: River/lake flooding can inundate building interiors, erode foundations and surrounding property, and decrease user accessibility.
river/lake flooding.notes: If you are unable to undertake a more detailed climate change/flood assessment for your building, conservative approach that assumes that flooding will increase in severity and frequency may be safest option.

sea level rise.direction_statement: Relative sea level is expected to rise along many Canadian coastlines.  However, particularly in the North, sea level may actually fall because of ongoing natural land uplift.
sea level rise.direction_confidence: There is reasonably high confidence in the direction of projected sea level changes around Canada's coastlines.
sea level rise.magnitude_confidence: There is less confidence in the exact magnitude of changes to sea level at specific locations.
sea level rise.impact_statement: Via coastal flood events, sea level rise can indundate building interiors, erode foundations and surrounding property, and decrease user accessibility.
sea level rise.notes: Remember, sea level rise will most likely impact your building through it's role in increasing the severity and frequency of storm and tide-driven extreme coastal flooding events.

extreme rain.direction_statement: Climate change is expected to cause extreme rain events to become more frequent and severe.
extreme rain.impact_statement: Extreme rain can directly damage building components through leaks and infiltration, and also inundate building interiors, erode foundations and surrounding property, and decrease user accessibility from rain-caused overland or flooding.

extreme heat.direction_statement: Climate change is expected to cause heat waves to become more frequent and severe.
extreme heat.impact_statement: Extreme heat can stress building air conditioning systems and cause damage by thermal expansion.

extreme cold.direction_statement: Climate change is expected to cause extreme cold snaps to become less frequent and severe.
extreme cold.impact_statement: Extreme cold can stress building heating systems and cause damage by thermal contraction.

extreme snow.direction_statement: Extreme snow accumulations over the winter season are likely to decrease in most areas of Canada, with the exception of the North.  Conversely, individual extreme mid-winter snowstorms may become more severe in many Canadian locations.
extreme snow.impact_statement: Extreme snow can stress roofs and decrease user accessibility.

permafrost loss.direction_statement: Permafrost extent and thickness is expected to decrease with climate change.  Active layer depths will increase.
permafrost loss.impact_statement: Permafrost loss can cause building subsidence, weaken foundations, promote moisture infiltration, and decrease user accessibility.

high winds.direction_statement: High wind events have the potential to become more severe with climate change in some Canadian locations.
high winds.impact_statement: High winds can damage building envelopes and exterior structures and influence building influence heating and cooling systems.

wildfire.direction_statement: Wildfires are expected to worsen in intensity and severity with climate change.
wildfire.impact_statement: Wildfire can damage and destroy buildings directly, and also degrade interior air quality through smoke.
